abstracts.cdata!:
The overall outcome of the project is
            rated as satisfactory, while project sustainability is rated
            as borderline "likely." Both World Bank and
            Borrower performances are assessed as satisfactory. These
            are some of the lesson learned: Grant, not credit, finance
            should be considered for initial social assistance in
            agriculture in post-conflict situations. In agriculture,
            attention to project design and implementation should always
            be given to linkages among producers, processors, and
            markets even if the project has social assistance
            objectives. In all sectors, greater development impacts
            might have been achieved with complementary investments in
            technical assistance and more focus on institutional
            strengthening. For example, provision of resources to
            farmers would have benefited from accompanying technical
            support, in the form of professional advice to farmers on
            such issues as animal nutrition and husbandry, and machinery
            use. In the housing sector, more consideration might have
            been given to occupancy issues, given their
            sensitivity--i.e., the design of the project meant that the
            Bank had little leverage over municipalities in the case
            that they obstructed return of original residents to their
            homes. This raises the issue of the degree to which the Bank
            can make use of non-economic conditionality to support
            social reconciliation in post-conflict situations. Reliance
            on local counterparts for project management and
            implementation strengthens institutional capacity.
